{{For|the 2006 movie adaptation|The Ant Bully (film)}} {{Unreferenced|date=July 2010}} {{Infobox book | name = The Ant Bully | image = The Ant Bully book cover.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = ''The Ant Bully'' book cover | author = [[John Nickle]] | illustrator = [[John Nickle]] | language = English | genre = [[Children's literature]]
[[Fantasy]] | publisher = | pub_date = 1999 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 0590395912 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = }} {{Portal |Children's literature}} '''''The Ant Bully''''' ({{ISBN|0590395912}}) is a 1999 [[children's book]] drawn and written by [[John Nickle]]. It is about a young boy named Lucas Nickle (also known as Peanut the Destroyer), who is the [[title character]] in the book and who likes to torment [[ant]]s. It was later adapted into a [[The Ant Bully (film)|computer-animated film of the same name]] by [[John A. Davis]], produced by [[Legendary Pictures]] and [[DNA Productions]] for [[Warner Bros. Pictures]]. ==Story== Lucas is a boy who is perceived as "strange" by his peers due to his funny glasses and propeller beanie (hat). Sid, the neighborhood bully, continuously bullies Lucas by spraying him with a water hose and stealing his hat. In an attempt to cope with Sid's actions, Lucas projects his anger onto a local colony of ants by spraying them with water, just as Sid has done to him. The ants have enough and tackle and shove Lucas into the queen's chamber, and the queen confronts him about all of the trouble he has caused the colony. When Lucas is too shocked to even respond to her, the queen takes it as an insult, and orders an ant wizard to shrink the boy down to the size of an ant and take him to trial, where the judge declares him guilty. His punishment is to work hard like an ant, working in the field, gathering food, defending the colony from wasps and spiders, and taking care of the queen, the worst part of his punishment. After a while, the queen tells Lucas that he has one last test to be set free: he must go home and bring her a Red Sweet Rock (jelly bean). Lucas brings two ants with him on the journey, and they ask him what it's like being a giant. Lucas tells them that he isn't a giant and gets picked on by Sid, who does all the same things Lucas does to the ants. When they reach his house, they find a box of swell jells, but Lucas's father sees the ants and tries to smash them with a fly swatter. Lucas shouts at his dad to stop, helping the ants to escape. Meanwhile, the queen is upset, fearing that Lucas was killed, but to her surprise he returns, and as promised she gives him the potion to return him to his right size. Lucas falls asleep and wakes up to see Sid, only to his surprise the ants got to him first and shrunk him as revenge. ==External links== * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080505004852/http://johnnickle.net/html/antbully.html The Ant Bully]'' at JohnNickle.net *''[http://readingtokids.org/Books/BookView.php?bookID=00000686 ReadingtoKids.org ]'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Ant Bully, The}} [[Category:1999 children's books]] [[Category:American picture books]] [[Category:Children's fiction books]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Fiction about insects]] {{child-picture-book-stub}} [[de:Lucas, der Ameisenschreck]]

{{infobox book | | name = The Informant | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:art9000widea.jpg | caption = | author = [[Kurt Eichenwald]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Lysine price-fixing conspiracy]] | genre = | publisher = [[Random House]] ([[hardback]])
[[Broadway Books]] ([[paperback]]s) | pub_date = | release_date = [[2000]] | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 624 (hardback)
656 ([[Paperback#Trade paperback|trade paperback]] and [[movie tie-in]] edition) | isbn = 978-0-7679-0326-4 | dewey= 364.16/8/0973 1 | congress= HV8144.F43 E53 2000 | oclc= 44045679 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Informant''''' is a [[nonfiction]] [[white-collar crime]] book written by journalist [[Kurt Eichenwald]] and published in 2000 by [[Random House]].{{cite news |last=Webber |first=Susan |title=Tale of the Tapes |work=The Daily Deal |publisher=[[Aurora Advisors]], Inc. |date=2000-09-25 |url=http://www.auroraadvisors.com/articles/2000-09_dailydeal.html |accessdate=2008-10-02}} It documents the mid-1990s [[lysine price-fixing conspiracy]] case and the involvement of [[Archer Daniels Midland]] executive [[Mark Whitacre]], inspiring [[The Informant!|a film adaptation]] starring [[Matt Damon]] as Whitacre. ==Summary== {{see also|Lysine price-fixing conspiracy}} {{external media| float = right| video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?160555-1/informant-true-story-part-1 Part One of ''Booknotes'' interview with Kurt Eichenwald on ''The Informant'', February 4, 2001], [[C-SPAN]]| video2 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?160555-2/informant-true-story-part-2 Part Two of ''Booknotes'' interview, February 11, 2001], [[C-SPAN]]}} In the early 1990s, at the [[agri-business]] conglomerate [[Archer Daniels Midland]] (ADM), [[Mark Whitacre]] is a corporate vice president and head of the bio-products division. In November 1992, under pressure from his wife, Whitacre confesses to an [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent that he, along with other ADM executives, routinely met with competitors to fix the price of [[lysine]], a food additive. Afterwards, Whitacre assists in gathering evidence against the other conspirators by secretly taping their activities during overseas business meetings. Over the course of three years, the FBI collects hundreds of hours of video and audio tapes documenting the largest case of price-fixing in history. Whitacre is revealed to have defrauded $9 million from ADM at the same time he was aiding the FBI. After federal agents stage raid on ADM, the company hits back with damning evidence against the government's star witness. Whitacre becomes delusional and engages in [[pathological lying]] to save himself, leading the FBI to learn that he suffers from [[bipolar disorder]]. Worst of all, he gives false stories to the media about being forced to destroy evidence by the FBI. Whitacre becomes extremely manic, stops sleeping, and exhibits bizarre behavior as his meltdown continues. He attempts suicide a few months later, but is saved by his groundskeeper. After seeing the movie ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'', Whitacre's delusional fantasy causes him to record and collect his conversations with FBI agents. Because he violated his immunity agreement with the government, Whitacre is charged with price-fixing along with the other ADM conspirators. Whitacre's attorney, James Epstein, successfully convinces the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] officials that the government was culpable for Whitacre's behavior as he was emotionally unprepared for the case. Epstein manages to get a very light sentence for Whitacre. However, Whitacre, unwilling to serve any jail time, fires Epstein. At his trial, Whitacre is convicted and receives a federal prison sentence three times longer than the other conspirators. Whitacre's FBI handlers, along with [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[John Ashcroft]], attempt to obtain a [[presidential pardon]] for Whitacre. With remarkable support from the FBI and his wife, Whitacre recovers from his mental problems and, after leaving prison, is promoted to COO and president of a California biotechnology company.{{cite news |author=Staff writers |title=Mark Whitacre, Ph.D. Promoted at Cypress Systems, Inc. and a Warner Bros. Movie to be Filmed About Him |work=News Blaze |date=2008-03-25 |url=http://newsblaze.com/story/2008032422530100001.sp/newsblaze/SENDPRES/Send2Press.html}}{{cite news |last=Ackerman |first=Ruthie |title=Whitacre’s Star Rises Again |work=Forbes |date=2008-03-27 |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/03/25/whitacre-adm-cypress-face-markets-cx_ra_0325autofacescan03.html}} The guilty parties in the price-fixing conspiracy, including ADM, pay hundreds of millions of dollars in settlements and fines, while several ADM executives serve prison time. ==Film adaptation== {{Main|The Informant!}} The book was used as the basis for the movie ''The Informant!'', directed by [[Steven Soderbergh]] and starring [[Matt Damon]] as Mark Whitacre. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.randomhouse.com/features/informant/home.html The Informant — Kurt Eichenwald] — official [[Random House]] website *[http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/168/The-Fix-Is-In ''This American Life'' #168: The Fix Is In] (RealAudio) — interview with [[Mark Whitacre]] and the book's author, [[Kurt Eichenwald]], from ''[[This American Life]]'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Informant (Book)}} [[Category:2000 books]] [[Category:Agriculture books]] [[Category:Archer Daniels Midland]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Books about bipolar disorder]] [[Category:Books about companies]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Commercial crimes]] [[Category:Ethics books]] [[Category:Price fixing convictions]] [[Category:Random House books]]

[[File:Ostrakon satire trades Turin.JPG|thumb|220px|[[19th Dynasty]] ostrakon inscribed with part of the ''Satire of the trades''. Turin, [[Museo Egizio]]]]{{Italic title}} '''''The Satire of the Trades''''', also called '''''The Instruction of Dua-Kheti''''', is a work of [[wikt:didactic|didactic]] ancient Egyptian literature.<ref>Katheryn A. Bard, ''Encyclopedia of the Archaeology of Ancient Egypt'', Routledge 1999, p.886</ref> It takes the form of an [[Sebayt|Instruction]], composed by a scribe from Sile named Dua-Kheti for his son Pepi. The author is thought by some to have composed the ''[[Instructions of Amenemhat]]'' as well.<ref>I. E. S. Edwards, N. G. L. Hammond, C. J. Gadd, ''The Cambridge Ancient History'', Cambridge University Press 1975, p.527</ref>
==Description== It describes a number of trades in an exaggeratedly negative light, extolling the advantages of the profession of scribe. It is generally considered to be a [[satire]], though [[Wolfgang Helck|Helck]] thought it reflected the true attitude of the scribal class towards manual labourers.<ref>W. Helck, ''Die Lehre des DwA-xtjj'', Wiesbaden, 1970</ref>
It was written during the [[Middle Kingdom of Egypt]], between 2025 and 1700 BC. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://knowledge.sagepub.com/view/disability/n852.xml|title=SAGE Knowledge - Home|website=knowledge.sagepub.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-28}}</ref>
The text has survived in its entirety, but extremely corrupted, in the Sallier II Papyrus written during the [[Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt|Nineteenth Dynasty]], which is kept at the [[British Museum]]. A number of fragments are kept at the British Museum, the [[Louvre]], the [[Pierpont Morgan Library]], and other institutions.<ref>Lichtheim, ''op.cit.'', pp.184f.</ref> It was one of the texts most frequently copied by students during the [[Ramesside Period]].
==Use of the Satire in Ben Sira== This Egyptian tale is referenced by [[Ben Sira]] in the [[Deuterocanonical]] ''Book of [[Sirach]]'' at {{bibleref|Sirach|38:24–39:11}}.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Ben Sira 38:24–39:11 and ''The Egyptian Satire of the Trades''|last=Rollston|first=Chris A.|journal=Journal of Biblical Literature|pages=131–139|volume=120|issue=Spring|date=April 2001|doi=10.2307/3268597}}</ref>
==References== *M. Lichtheim, ''Ancient Egyptian Literature'', volume I, 1973, pp. 184-193 *S. Quirke, Egyptian Literature 1800 BC, questions and readings, London 2004, pp. 121-126
==External links== *[http://www.reshafim.org.il/ad/egypt/texts/instructions_of_kheti.htm An English translation of The Satire of the Trades]
==Footnotes== <references />

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=December 2015}} {{about|the satirical painting by South African artist Brett Murray|the novel by James Herbert|The Spear}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file = The_Spear_-_a_portrait_of_Jacob_Zuma,_by_Brett_Murray.jpg | alt=See adjacent text. | image_size=250px | title=The Spear | artist=[[Brett Murray]] | year=2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newzimbabwe.com/opinion-8058-Why+Zumas+Spear+should+stay+up/opinion.aspx |title=Why Zuma's Spear should stay up |publisher=Newzimbabwe.com |date=23 May 2012 |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref>| type=[[Acrylic Paint|Acrylic]] on [[canvas]] | height_metric=185 | width_metric=140 | height_imperial=72.8 | width_imperial=55 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Johannesburg]] | museum=[[Goodman Gallery]] }} '''''The Spear''''' is a painting by [[Cape Town]]-based South African artist, [[Brett Murray]]. It depicts South African President [[Jacob Zuma]] in a pose reminiscent of [[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]], with his genitals exposed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Govender|first=Peroshni|title=Presidential penis portrait riles S. Africa's ANC|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE84H07820120518|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> The painting triggered a defamation lawsuit by Zuma's party, the [[African National Congress]] (ANC), and was vandalised on 22 May 2012.
== Exhibition == Prior to its being vandalised, ''The Spear'' was shown at the Goodman Gallery in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa. The painting featured as one of the pieces of artist Brett Murray's ''Hail to the Thief II'' exhibition, which commenced on 10 May 2012.<ref name=Goodman/> Inspiration is understood to have been drawn from the [[Viktor Semyonovich Ivanov]]'s poster ''Lenin Lived, Lenin is Alive, Lenin Will Live''.<ref>{{cite web|title=The painting of President Zuma|url=http://inside-politics.org/2012/05/17/the-painting-of-president-zuma/|work=www.inside-politics.org|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> The exhibition features various pieces that are critical of South Africa's ruling party, the ANC, showcasing sculptures and images that suggest [[corruption]] and bad governance.<ref name=Goodman>{{cite web|title=Goodman Gallery - Hail to the Thief II|url=http://www.goodman-gallery.com/exhibitions/265|publisher=Goodman Gallery|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> Murray's works in the exhibition also include modifying ANC liberation struggle posters and flyers from the [[Apartheid]] era, some displaying the text "Amandla, we demand Chivas, BMWs and bribes".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/saturday-star/it-s-staying-up-1.1302261 |title=It’s staying up! |author=Sameer Naik and Kashiefa Ajam |date=22 May 2012 |work=The Saturday Star |accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref>
== Public perception of Jacob Zuma == Zuma has often been the centre of scandal and ridicule, due to his polygamous lifestyle with many wives and girlfriends,<ref>{{cite web|title=Jacob Zuma - "Polygamy is part of my culture"|url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/article/jacob-zuma-polygamy-part-my-culture|publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> and a comment he made during his 2006 [[Jacob Zuma rape trial|rape trial]] that showering after sex would minimise the risk of contracting [[HIV]].<ref>{{cite news|title=SA's Zuma 'showered to avoid HIV'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4879822.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> His lifestyle has made him the target of well-known cartoonist [[Zapiro]], who frequently depicts Zuma with a shower on his head, ridiculing the statements he made during his trial.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nicolaides|first=Gia|title=Zapiro revives showerhead|url=http://news.iafrica.com/sa/574737.html|publisher=iafrica.com|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> Zapiro was also sued for defamation by the ANC, with a hearing expected in October 2012.<ref name=BBC185 /> These public perceptions of Zuma provided part of the basis for Brett Murray's painting.<ref name=BBC185>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18115724 |title=Jacob Zuma painting: ANC to sue South Africa's Brett Murray |date=18 May 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref>
Zapiro added fuel to the fire by doing his own version of the painting, replacing the genitals with a showerhead.<ref name=Zapiro185>{{cite web |url=http://www.zapiro.com/cartoon/890737-120520st |title=Published in Sunday Times on 20 May 2012 |date=20 May 2012 |publisher=Zapiro |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> Another appeared two days later, ridiculing Zuma.<ref name=Zapiro186>{{cite web |url=http://www.zapiro.com/cartoon/892612-120522tt |title=120522tt - President Zuma outraged at Brett Murray's Painting - Spear of the Nation |date=22 May 2012 |publisher=Zapiro |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref>
== ANC response ==
Owner and director of the Goodman Gallery, Liza Essers, said that she received a telephone call on Sunday, 13 May 2012 from special advisor to the minister of arts and culture Mduduzi Mbata seeking to clarify her thoughts on the exhibition, after it had been reviewed in the newspaper [[City Press (South Africa)|''City Press'']], along with a photograph of ''The Spear''. During the brief conversation she invited him to visit the gallery the following Tuesday, but he never kept the appointment.<ref name=AiA>{{cite web|last=Dubin|first=Steven|title=Liza Essers, Gallery Owner, on the Show that Scandalized South Africa|url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-opinion/conversations/2012-06-05/liza-essers-brent-murray-goodman-gallery/|work=Art in America|publisher=Art in America|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=5 June 2012}}</ref>
The ANC issued a press release on 17 May 2012 expressing outrage about the painting and their intention to apply to the High Court to have it removed, this being reiterated by attorneys representing the ANC and Jacob Zuma in an email sent to Essers the same day.<ref name=AiA/> The painting drew strong condemnation from ANC rulers and various religious groups, who found the painting 'obscene' and 'vulgar'.<ref name="mosomane1">{{cite web|last=Mosomane|first=Phuti|title=Zuma painting against Ubuntu, African morality, culture|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/Detail.aspx?news_id=51152&cat_id=1007|publisher=The New Age|accessdate=19 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526184457/http://www.thenewage.co.za/Detail.aspx?news_id=51152&cat_id=1007|archivedate=26 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A leader of the Nazareth Baptist Church called for the artist to be stoned to death.<ref name=AiA/> The ANC also demanded that the image be taken down from the [[City Press (South Africa)|''City Press'']]' website. ANC spokesperson Jackson Mthembu said of the painting, "The African National Congress is extremely disturbed and outraged by the distasteful and indecent manner in which Brett Murray and the Goodman Gallery in Johannesburg is displaying the person of comrade President Jacob Zuma".<ref>{{cite web|title=ANC to go to court over Zuma painting|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/ANC-to-go-to-court-over-Zuma-painting-20120517|publisher=News24.com|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> Zuma responded to the artwork by saying that it painted him as "a philanderer and a womaniser".<ref>{{cite news|title=Painting makes me a womaniser - Zuma|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/painting-makes-me-a-womaniser-zuma-1.1300191|accessdate=20 May 2012|newspaper=IOL.co.za|date=20 May 2012}}</ref>
In response to the impending legal action, gallery spokesperson Lara Koseff said its lawyers had responded that it would stay until the show was over, citing censorship concerns as central to the decision to allow the exhibition to continue.<ref name="mosomane1"/> The [[African National Congress Women's League|ANC Women's League]] has also demanded that the exhibition be halted, and all instances of the image be removed from the internet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Painting violates president's integrity, says ANCWL|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2012/05/19/painting-violates-president-s-integrity-says-ancwl|accessdate=19 May 2012|newspaper=Times Live|date=19 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Stephen|first=Grootes|title=Zuma portrait saga goes to court|url=http://www.ewn.co.za/en/2012/05/19/Zuma%20portrait%20saga%20goes%20to%20court.aspx|accessdate=19 May 2012|newspaper=Eyewitness News|date=19 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602173211/http://ewn.co.za/en/2012/05/19/Zuma%20portrait%20saga%20goes%20to%20court.aspx|archivedate=2 June 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Brett Murray said that his painting had not been intended maliciously, but as "an attempt at humorous satire of political power and patriarchy within the context of other artworks in the exhibition and within the broader context of South African discourse".<ref name=N24Defaced />
In the first day of legal proceedings, the representative for the ANC, Gcina Malindi, began sobbing and was unable to proceed, causing the process to be adjorned and postponed and the television coverage of the event was suppressed. Later, the ANC sought to drop proceedings.<ref>{{cite news|title=Zuma lawyers tears as court hears rude painting case|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18186692|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=BBC News with video|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=ANC advocate sobs in court|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/ANC-advocate-sobs-in-court-20120524|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=News24|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='South Africa court hears Jacob Zuma obscene painting case|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18182318|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Conway-Smith|first=Erin|title=Jacob Zuma The Spear painting case postponed indefinitely|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/africa/south-africa/120524/the-spear-jacob-zuma-painting-court-case-anc-lawyer|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=GlobalPost|date=24 May 2012}}</ref>
=== Consequences === The ANC's public condemnation of the painting brought widespread local and international attention to the painting, where otherwise it may have remained a relatively obscure piece of work. For this reason, the action and subsequent fall-out has been characterised as an example of the [[Streisand effect]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Just Hanging Out|url=http://6000.co.za/just-hanging-out/|publisher=6000 Miles from Civilization|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mahere|first=Fadzayi|title=Why Zuma's Spear should stay up|url=http://www.newzimbabwe.com/opinion-8058-Why+Zumas+Spear+should+stay+up/opinion.aspx|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=New Zimbabwe|date=23 May 2012}}</ref> Subsequently, ''The Spear'' has been featured in editorials and news features in all forms of traditional and digital media.
Former ANC leader [[Oliver Tambo]]’s daughter Tselane Tambo was of the opinion that Zuma deserved Murray’s portrayal of him. She wrote on a social networking site, “Do the poor enjoy poverty? Do the unemployed enjoy hopelessness? Do those who can’t get housing enjoy homelessness? He must get over it. No one is having a good time. He should inspire the reverence he craves. This portrait is what he inspired. Shame neh!”.<ref>{{cite news|title=Video: Zuma’s Spear painting sabotage|url=http://www.thesouthafrican.com/news/spear-today-gone-tomorrow.htm|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=The South African .com|date=22 May 2012}}</ref>
The media boycott of ''City Press'' by the ANC and various public figures led to the newspaper eventually removing the painting from its website on 28 May 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=de Waal|first=Mandy|title=City Press buckles to ANC demands - and threats|url=http://dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-05-28-city-press-buckles-to-anc-demands-and-threats|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Daily Maverick|date=28 May 2012}}</ref> The paper's editor-in-chief Ferial Haffajee cited several reasons for this decision, including violent threats made to her team by those supporting the boycott.{{or|date=July 2012}}
=== Media boycott === After ''City Press'' repeatedly refused to remove an image of the painting off their website, the ANC called upon its members and sympathisers to boycott placing advertising in, and buying of, the weekly paper. A statement released by the ANC said: "Their refusal to remove this portrait from their website and their controlled social media is a clear indication that this newspaper does not belong to our shared democratic dispensation and values." Responding to the boycott, ''City Press'' editor-in-chief [[Ferial Haffajee]] described Nzimande's call for a boycott of the paper as "deeply disturbing".<ref>{{cite news|title=Boycott 'immoral' ''City Press'', ANC urges|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Boycott-City-Press-the-paragon-of-immorality-ANC-20120524-2|accessdate=25 May 2012|newspaper=News24.co.za|date=25 May 2012}}</ref>
The ANC was criticised by the South African National Editors' Forum (SANEF),<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=David|title=Zuma genitals row escalates as ANC calls for boycott of newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/25/zuma-genitals-row-anc-newspaper-boycott|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=25 May 2012}}</ref> which said "While we recognise the right of the ANC to advise members on how to exercise their consumer decisions, the call for a boycott of a newspaper is tantamount to intimidation and abuse of power ... This kind of behaviour is unbecoming of a party that functions in an open democratic stage and especially one which leads the national government."<ref>{{cite web|title=Sanef alarmed at call by the ANC to boycott City Press Newspaper (Press release)|url=http://sanef.org.za/news/entry/sanef_alarmed_at_the_call_by_the_anc_to_boycott_city_press_newspaper/|work=South African National Editors' Forum website|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=24 May 2012}}</ref> The boycott of City Press was further condemned by the [[International Press Institute]] (IPI),<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2012/may/28/southafrica-press-freedom South African newspaper defies ANC boycott call]</ref> and by 28 May, ten days after the newspaper printed the painting for the first time, opinions in the ANC had divided with several senior members opposing the boycott.<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenslade|first=Roy|title=South African newspaper defies ANC boycott call|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2012/may/28/southafrica-press-freedom|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Greenslade Blog - The Guardian|date=28 May 2012}}</ref>
== Defacement == On the morning of 22 May 2012, two men entered the gallery during visiting hours, and defaced the painting - first by painting a red cross over the depiction of Zuma's face and genitals, and then by smearing black paint over the canvas. The two men — Barend la Grange and Lowie Mabokela<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/global/2012/05/painting-south-african-presidents-penis-defaced/52698/ |title=Painting of South African President's Penis Defaced |author=Adam Martin |date=23 May 2012 |work=The Atlantic |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> — were arrested by security officials. This defacement took place whilst court proceedings brought on by the ANC around the right to censor the image were underway.<ref name=N24Defaced>{{cite news|last=Pasley-Banks|first=Carrin|title=Zuma painting defaced at Goodman Gallery|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Zuma-painting-defaced-at-Goodman-Gallery-20120522|accessdate=22 May 2012|publisher=News24|date=22 May 2012|quote=The controversial painting depicting President Jacob Zuma with his genitals exposed was defaced by two men at the Goodman Gallery in Johannesburg on Tuesday.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Zuma 'penis painting' defaced|url=http://news.iafrica.com/sa/795807.html|accessdate=22 May 2012|newspaper=iafrica.com|date=22 May 2012}}</ref>
The way in which the two men were arrested also drew criticism: Barend la Grange was arrested without any apparent violence, while Lowie Mabokela was head-butted and thrown to the ground.<ref>{{cite news|last=Herskovitz|first=Jon|title=South Africa painting debate exposes racial rifts|url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUSBRE84M04O20120524|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Reuters|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Gallery security guard arrested over Zuma painting incident|url=http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2012/05/23/gallery-security-guard-arrested-over-zuma-painting-incident|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Sowetan Live|date=23 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=David|title=Zuma portrait court case reopens South Africa's wounds from apartheid era|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/24/spear-zuma-portrait-court-apartheid|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 May 2012}}</ref>
== Classification == On 22 May 2012, the [[Films and Publications Act, 1996|Film and Publication Board (FPB)]] of South Africa announced that a team of five classifiers had been sent to assess ''The Spear'',<ref name=fpb20120522>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=FPB Classification of 'The Spear' Artwork as Displayed at the Goodman Gallery (PDF document) |work=FPB.gov.za |url=http://www.fpb.gov.za/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=163&tmpl=component&format=raw&Itemid=103 |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=22 May 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> following specific complaints to the FPB, which is the statutory body responsible for classifying, and applying age ratings and content advisories to, works published or distributed in South Africa,<ref name=fpbzaabout>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Film and Publication Board Profile |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/profile-fpb |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> including films, computer games, images of all kinds, and printed publications;<ref name=fpb20120601>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=FPB Classification of 'The Spear' Artwork (PDF document) |work=FPB.gov.za |url=http://www.fpb.gov.za/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=169&tmpl=component&format=raw&Itemid=103 |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref>{{rp|1, 3}} however, "Only pornographic publications need to be passed by the FPB before they are released on the market" while others are considered based on "complaints received from the public regarding specific publications",<ref name=fpbclassification>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Classification of Films, Games and Publications |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/classifications |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> and the [[Films and Publications Act, 1996|FPB's]] jurisdiction specifically excludes newspapers<ref name="fpb20120601" />{{rp|3}}<ref name=timeslive20120529a>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title='We don't rule over City Press', says FPB |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2012/05/29/we-don-t-rule-over-city-press-says-fpb |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=iol20120601>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Board explains Spear 16N rating |work=IOL.co.za |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/the-zuma-era/board-explains-spear-16n-rating-1.1309795 |publisher=Independent Online |location=Cape Town, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> and the broadcast media,<ref name="timeslive20120529a"/><ref name=fpbzahome>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Home |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/ |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> which are regulated by separate entities. For this reason, the FPB proceedings could only consider the painting itself, its display by the gallery, and its publication or possible publication on websites or in other venues subject to FPB jurisdiction; and could not address the publication of images of it by newspapers or broadcasters.<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|3}}<ref name="timeslive20120529a"/><ref name="iol20120601"/> During the classification proceedings, there were allegations that the FPB was acting outside its statutory remit,<ref name=timeslive20120529b>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Board has no right to classify "The Spear": lawyer |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/scitech/2012/05/29/board-has-no-right-to-classify-the-spear-lawyer |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> and that specific members had made statements or asked questions implying that it was entitled to censor political opinions and restrict freedom of the press.<ref name=mg20120530>{{cite news |first=Phillip |last=de Wet |title='The Spear': It's classified, and now up to the ombud |work=mg.co.za |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2012-05-30-fpb-its-our-duty-to-classify-the-spear-and-suppress-criticism/ |publisher=Mail & Guardian |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=30 May 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref>
On 1 June 2012, the FPB announced that the classifiers assigned to 'The Spear' had rejected a complainant's call for the painting to be rated X18<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|5}} (placing it within the category of legal [[pornography|pornographic]] works that must "be passed by the FPB before they are released on the market",<ref name="fpbclassification"/> and that may be distributed only by licensed distributors, who are required to obtain proof of age<ref name=fpbzafpact2009>{{cite journal |author=Government of the Republic of South Africa |title=Regulations - Film and Publication Act 3 of 2009 |journal=Government Gazette, Republic of South Africa |volume=537 |issue=33026 |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/profile-fpb/2012-05-23-04-21-16/doc_details/108-regulations-fpb-amendment-act-3-of-2009 |publisher=Government Printer |location=Pretoria, South Africa |date=15 March 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>{{rp|19}}), but had decided on a 16N rating for the original, undefaced and uncensored, painting, meaning that measures should be put in place to prevent access to it and to images of it by those under the age of sixteen, and to advise "sensitive adult viewers" over sixteen that it contains nudity (but not explicit sexual content, which would have been designated by an S in the rating).<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|5}}<ref name="iol20120601"/><ref name=mg20120601>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title='The Spear' gets 16N rating |work=mg.co.za |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2012-06-01-the-spear-gets-16n-rating |publisher=Mail & Guardian |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=timeslive20120601>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Censors rate Spear 16N for nudity |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2012/06/01/censors-rate-spear-16n-for-nudity |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> In its press statement announcing the classification, the FPB referred at length to its statutory authority and responsibilities, in particular its role in "promoting the safety of children";<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|1}} and explicitly denied that it had been influenced by political figures or had acted beyond its jurisdiction, saying that "We believe that reports to the contrary have been specifically designed to defame the Film and Publication Board, question its integrity, competence, credibility as well as formulate as a reality the false notion that the state seeks to silence and censor the media by all means possible and with total disregard for accepted procedures and principles".<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|3}} In reply to questions, FPB chief operations officer Mmapula Fisha said that ''The Spear'' differed from other works of art containing nudity, and merited the 16N classification, because "The artwork has forced society to revisit its painful history".<ref name="iol20120601"/> After the classification was announced, the Goodman Gallery was reported to be seeking legal advice, but to have said they "felt it would have a significant impact on freedom of artistic expression",<ref name=iol20120601at18h24>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Gallery studying ‘Spear’ classification |work=IOL.co.za |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/gallery-studying-spear-classification-1.1310184 |publisher=Independent Online |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> a criticism also made by commentators not involved in the case,<ref name=sabc20120705>{{cite news |author=South African Broadcasting Corporation |title=Artists warned to exercise self-censorship following "The Spear" saga |work=SABC.co.za |url=http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/fdf12f804b81bf8cac20fe88d736c33c/Artists-warned-to-exercise-self-censorship-following-The-Spear-saga-20120605 |publisher=SABC |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=5 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> while others expressed concern about political censorship.<ref name=polity20120608hamber>{{cite news |first=Brandon |last=Hamber |title=Putting the Presidential pickle in perspective |work=Polity.org.za |url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/putting-the-presidential-pickle-in-perspective-2012-06-08 |publisher=Creamer Media |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=8 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=citypress20120603editorial>{{cite news |author=City Press Editor |title=FPB decision smacks of censorship |work=Citypress.co.za |url=http://www.citypress.co.za/Opinions/Editorials/FPB-decision-smacks-of-censorship-20120602 |publisher=City Press |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=3 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=dailymav20120606rousseau>{{cite news |first=Jacques |last=Rousseau |title=Censorship: The chilling effect |work=DailyMaverick.co.za |url=http://dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2012-06-06-censorship-the-chilling-effect |publisher=Daily Maverick |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=6 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=polweb20120604cfcr>{{cite news |first=Johan |last=Kruger |title=The FPB's classification of the Spear: The CFCR critique |work=Politicsweb.co.za |url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page71656?oid=303497&sn=Detail&pid=71656 |publisher=Politicsweb |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=4 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=da20120601smuts>{{cite news |first=Dene |last=Smuts |title=Spear saga: FPB protecting the President, not children |work=DA.org.za |url=http://www.da.org.za/newsroom.htm?action=view-news-item&id=10756 |publisher=Democratic Alliance |location=Cape Town, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=timeslive20120603huisman>{{cite news|first=Biénne |last=Huisman |title=Criticism over age limit on The Spear |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://m.timeslive.co.za/?name=timeslive&i=11263/1/0&artId=27753 |publisher=Times Live |location=Cape Town, South Africa |date=3 June 2012 |accessdate=3 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412061254/http://m.timeslive.co.za/?name=timeslive |archivedate=12 April 2012 }}</ref> The full report of the classification committee responsible for assessing ''The Spear'' was subsequently made available online.<ref name=fpb20120531report>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Recommendation for Classification of a Publication under Section 16(1) of the Film and Publication Act. Title: The Spear - Hail to the Thief II by Brett Murray (PDF document) |work=FPB.gov.za |url=http://www.fpb.gov.za/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=170&tmpl=component&format=raw&Itemid=103 |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=31 May 2012 |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> The classification was open to appeal.<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|2}}<ref name=fpbappealtrib>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=About the appeals tribunal |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/classifications/appeals-tribunal |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=22 May 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
On 10 July 2012, the Goodman Gallery announced that it would be appealing the classification decision,<ref name=citypress20120710>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Goodman appeals ‘Spear’ classification |work=Citypress.co.za |url=http://www.citypress.co.za/SouthAfrica/News/Goodman-appeals-Spear-classification-20120710 |publisher=City Press |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=10 July 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=timeslive20120710>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Gallery appeals 'Spear' classification |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2012/07/10/gallery-appeals-spear-classification |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=10 July 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> and the following day the FPB confirmed that an appeal had been lodged.<ref name=citypress20120711>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=‘The Spear’ appeal lodged |work=Citypress.co.za |url=http://www.citypress.co.za/Politics/News/The-Spear-appeal-lodged-20120711 |publisher=City Press |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=timeslive20120711>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title='Spear' appeal lodged with censors |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2012/07/11/spear-appeal-lodged-with-censors |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> On 13 September 2012, the Goodman Gallery made written submissions to the [[Films and Publications Act, 1996|Film and Publication Appeal Tribunal]], and its written arguments were also made available to the press.<ref name=mg20120913>{{cite news |first=Niren |last=Tolsi |title=Goodman Gallery appeals 'Spear' rating |work=mg.co.za |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2012-09-13-goodman-gallery-appeals-spear-rating |publisher=Mail & Guardian |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=13 September 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> The tribunal heard oral argument and evidence on 17 September 2012.<ref name="mg20120913" /><ref name=iol20120917at14h21>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Gallery’s ‘Spear’ appeal starts |work=IOL.co.za |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/gallery-s-spear-appeal-starts-1.1384789 |publisher=Independent Online |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=17 September 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=news24-20121011react>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Spear move sets 'crucial precedent' |work=News24.com |url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Spear-move-sets-crucial-precedent-20121011 |publisher=News24 |location=Cape Town, South Africa |date=11 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
On 10 October 2012, the FPB announced that the [[Films and Publications Act, 1996|Film and Publication Appeal Tribunal]] had upheld the Goodman Gallery's appeal, setting aside the classification and thereby removing all restrictions on publication of and access to the painting.<ref name=citypress20121010>{{cite news |author=City Press Staff Reporter |title=Appeal tribunal declassifies The Spear |work=Citypress.co.za |url=http://www.citypress.co.za/SouthAfrica/News/Appeal-tribunal-declassifies-The-Spear-20121010 |publisher=City Press |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010231019/http://www.citypress.co.za/SouthAfrica/News/Appeal-tribunal-declassifies-The-Spear-20121010 |archivedate=10 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=witness20121011>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association & Witness Reporter |title=The Spear: Classification of painting overturned on appeal |work=Witness.co.za |url=http://www.witness.co.za/index.php?showcontent&global%5B_id%5D=89155 |publisher=The Witness |location=Pietermaritzburg, South Africa |date=11 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=timeslive20121010>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title='The Spear' declassified |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2012/10/10/the-spear-declassified |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> The tribunal's full ruling<ref name=fpb20121007award>{{cite web |first=Karthy |last=Govender |title=Award In re: Appeal against the classification of the painting known as The Spear and the electronic versions of it (Microsoft Word 2007 .docx document) |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/images/documents/reviewawards/The_Spear_Appeal_Award.docx |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Durban, South Africa |date=7 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> was published on the same day.<ref name=fpb20121007pr>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Press Statement on the award in respect of the appeal for the FPB Classification of 'The Spear' painting as displayed at the Goodman Gallery |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/media-centre-fpb/press-release |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> The Appeal Tribunal approved the original Classification Committee's determination that ''The Spear'' should not be classed as [[pornography]],<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|5-7}} but found against the committee, its procedure, and its classification on several grounds, including that the decision had been based on flawed arguments and interpretation of the relevant law;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|7-11}} that the committee had relied on conclusions for which no evidence had been presented either during the original classification process or to the Appeal Tribunal;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|13}} that the FPB should not have considered a complaint against the publication of ''The Spear'' in newspapers or on their websites, because the FPB has no jurisdiction over such publications, and should instead have passed complaints against them on to the appropriate regulator;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|3}} that the committee had wrongly taken upon itself "responsibility for balancing conflicting rights" that properly belonged to the courts, and was beyond the "much narrower mandate [of] the Classification Committee";<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|10-1}} that the FPB had wrongly, and in violation both of the rights of their publishers and of legal principles of procedural fairness, "appeared to extend its ruling to all websites that contained electronic replications of the painting and to all other publications of the painting", rather than restricting its decision to the specific named respondents who had been accorded an opportunity to make representations during the classification process;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|3-4}} that due weight had not been given to the painting's status as a work of agreed artistic merit enjoying greater statutory protection from both publication and age restrictions;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|11-3, 7}} that the committee had wrongly deemed nudity ''per se'' to be grounds for considering a work of art "potentially disturbing, harmful, or inappropriate to children";<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|13}} and that the committee had used the system of "restrictive age classifications" designed solely to "protect children" (and not adults) from potentially "disturbing, harmful, or age-inappropriate material" and "from premature exposure to adult experiences"<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|9-11}} in a way that "was not legally permissible" for "the purposes of protecting sensitive viewers or assuaging the sense of indignity felt by some segments of the community"<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|11}} by effectively restricting adults' access to a published work that was neither illegal nor [[pornography|pornographic]].<ref name="citypress20121010"/><ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|7-11}}
==Comparisons== ''The Spear'' portrait has invited comparison to other satirical pieces, including fellow South African artist [[Ayanda Mabulu|Ayanda Mabulu's]] work, ''{{lang|zu|Ngcono ihlwempu kunesibhanxo sesityebi}}'' (Zulu: "Better poor than a rich puppet"), which depicts various regional and international political figures - including Jacob Zuma - in the nude. The painting received additional attention following the media focus on controversial satirical artworks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Butana|first=Kwanele|title=Cape artist despairs for ‘illiterate’ ANC|url=http://www.iol.co.za/the-star/cape-artist-despairs-for-illiterate-anc-1.1302504|publisher=iol.co.za|accessdate=25 May 2012}}</ref>

{{redirect|Time warp|3=Time Warp (disambiguation)}}[[File:Poster for the 1960 film The Time Machine.jpg|thumb|right|Poster for the 1960 film adaptation of H. G. Wells' story]] [[Time travel]] is a common theme in [[fiction]] and has been [[List of time travel works of fiction|depicted in a variety of media]], such as literature, television, film, and advertisements.<ref name="Nahin">{{cite book|last1=Nahin|first1=Paul J.|title=Time Machines: Time Travel in Physics, Metaphysics, and Science Fiction|date=1999|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=9780387985718|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Nahin|first1=Paul J.|title=Time Travel: A Writer's Guide to the Real Science of Plausible Time Travel|date=2011|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|location=Baltimore|isbn=1421401207|page=ix}}</ref>
The [[Time travel#History of the time travel concept|concept of time travel by mechanical means]] was popularized in [[H. G. Wells]]' 1895 story, ''[[The Time Machine]]''.<ref name="britannica1">{{cite web|last=Sterling|first=Bruce|url=https://www.britannica.com/art/science-fiction/Time-travel|title=Science fiction - Time travel|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|date=2016-05-03|accessdate=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref name="Kuiper">{{cite book|last1=Kuiper|first1=Kathleen|title=Prose: Literary Terms and Concepts|date=2012|publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.|Britannica Educational Publishing]]|location=New York|isbn=1615304940|pages=63-64|edition=1st}}</ref> In general, time travel stories focus on the consequences of traveling into the past or the future.<ref name="britannica1"/><ref name="britannica2">{{cite web|last=Sterling|first=Bruce|url=https://www.britannica.com/art/science-fiction/Time-travel#ref235732|title=Science fiction - Time travel|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|date=2016-05-03|accessdate=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref name="theguardian1">{{cite web|author=Alison Flood|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/sep/23/time-travel-in-fiction|title=Time travel in fiction: why authors return to it time and time again|work=The Guardian|date=2011-09-23|accessdate=2015-11-29}}</ref> The central premise for these stories oftentimes involves changing history, either intentionally or by accident, and the ways by which altering the past changes the future and creates an altered present or future for the time traveler when they return home.<ref name="britannica1"/><ref name="theguardian1"/> Some stories focus solely on the paradoxes and alternate timelines that come with time travel, rather than time traveling itself.<ref name="britannica2"/> They often provide some sort of social commentary, as time travel provides a "necessary distancing effect" that allows science fiction to address contemporary issues in metaphorical ways.<ref name=Redmond>{{cite book|last1=Redmond|first1=Sean|title=Liquid Metal: the Science Fiction Film Reader.|date=2014|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|isbn=0231501846|page=114|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iVQaAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA114&dq=necessary+distancing+effect&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMIv8un1K2fyAIVh9YUCh3-lgwa#v=onepage&q=necessary%20distancing%20effect&f=false|accessdate=30 September 2015}}</ref>
Time travel in modern fiction is sometimes achieved by [[Wormhole|space and time warps]], stemming from the scientific theory of [[general relativity]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Space and Time Warps|author=Stephen Hawking|date=1999|url=http://www.hawking.org.uk/space-and-time-warps.html|accessdate=February 20, 2016}}</ref> [[Time travel#History of the time travel concept|Stories from antiquity]] often featured time travel into the future through a [[#time slip|time slip]] brought on by traveling or sleeping,{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} or in other cases, time travel into the past through supernatural means, for example brought on by [[angel]]s<ref>{{cite book|last1=Alkon|first1=Paul K.|title=Origins of Futuristic Fiction|date=1987|publisher=University of Georgia Press|location=Athens|isbn=082030932X|pages=95–96}}</ref> or spirits.<ref name="Kuiper"/>
==Time travel themes==
===Changing the past=== The idea of changing the past is logically [[contradiction|contradictory]], and results in a [[grandfather paradox]].<ref name="unchangeable">{{cite web|author=Norman Swartz|title=Time Travel: Visiting the Past|url=https://www.sfu.ca/~swartz/time_travel1.htm|date=1993|publisher=SFU.ca|accessdate=February 20, 2016}}</ref> [[Paul J. Nahin]], who has written extensively on the topic of time travel in fiction, states that "[e]ven though the consensus today is that the past cannot be changed, science fiction writers have used the idea of changing the past for good story effect".<ref name="Nahin"/>{{rp|267}} Time travel to the past and [[#Precognition|precognition]] without the ability to change events may result in [[causal loop]]s.<ref name="Klosterman">{{cite book|last1=Klosterman|first1=Chuck|title=Eating the Dinosaur|date=2009|publisher=Scribner|location=New York|isbn=9781439168486|pages=60-62|edition=1st}}</ref>
The possibility of characters inadvertently or intentionally changing the past also gave rise to the idea of "time police", people tasked with preventing such changes from occurring by themselves engaging in time travel to rectify such changes.<ref name="Stableford">{{cite book|last1=Stableford|first1=Brian|title=Science Fact and Science Fiction: An Encyclopedia|date=2006|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=0415974607|page=534}}</ref>
====Alternative future, history, timelines, and dimensions==== {{See also|Parallel universe (fiction)|Future history|Alternate history|:Category:Multiple time paths in fiction}} An alternative future or alternate future is a possible [[future]] that never comes to pass, typically when someone travels back into the [[past]] and alters it so that the events of the alternative future cannot occur,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Prucher|first1=Jeffrey|last2=Wolfe|first2=Gene|title=Brave New Words: The Oxford Dictionary of Science Fiction|date=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780195305678|pages=4–5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iYzi8m8FbEsC&pg=PA4#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref> or when a communication from the future to the past effected a change that alters the future.<ref name="Nahin"/>{{rp|165}} Alternative histories may exist "side by side", with the time traveller actually arriving at different dimensions as he changes time.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Journeys in Space and Time|episode-link=|url=|accessdate=|series=[[Cosmos: A Personal Voyage]]|series-link=|first=|last=|network=[[PBS]]|station=|date=November 16, 1980|season=|series-no=|number=8|minutes=|time=36 minute mark|transcript=|transcript-url=|quote=|language=}}</ref>
====Butterfly effect==== The [[butterfly effect]] is the notion that small events can have large, widespread consequences. The term describes events observed in [[chaotic systems|chaos theory]] where a very small change in initial conditions results in vastly different outcomes. The term was coined by mathematician [[Edward Norton Lorenz|Edward Lorenz]] years after the phenomenon was first described.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hilborn|first1=Robert C.|title=Sea gulls, butterflies, and grasshoppers: A brief history of the butterfly effect in nonlinear dynamics|journal=[[American Journal of Physics]]|date=April 2004|volume=72|issue=4|pages=425–427|doi=10.1119/1.1636492|bibcode=2004AmJPh..72..425H}}</ref>
The butterfly effect has found its way into popular imagination. For example, in Ray Bradbury's 1952 short story ''[[A Sound of Thunder]]'', the killing of a single insect millions of years in the past drastically changes the world, and in the 2004 film ''[[The Butterfly Effect]]'', the protagonist's small changes to their past results in extreme changes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/bostonglobe/ideas/articles/2008/06/08/the_meaning_of_the_butterfly/?page=full|title=The meaning of the butterfly|author=Peter Dizikes|date=June 8, 2008|work=Boston Globe|accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref>
===Communication from the future=== In literature, [[communication]] from the future as a [[plot device]] is encountered in various [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] stories. [[Forrest J. Ackerman]] noted in his 1973 anthology of the best fiction of the year that "[t]he theme of getting hold of tomorrow's newspaper is a recurrent one".<ref name="Ackerman">[[Forrest J. Ackerman]], ed., ''Best Science Fiction for 1973'' (1973), p. 36.</ref> An early example of this device can be found in the [[H.G. Wells]] 1932 [[short story]] "[[The Queer Story of Brownlow's Newspaper]]",<ref name="Ackerman"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gutenberg.net.au/ebooks06/0601931h.html|title=The Queer Story of Brownlow's Newspaper|publisher=Gutenberg.net.au|date=1971-11-10|accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref> which tells the tale of a man who receives such a paper from 40 years in the future. The 1944 film ''[[It Happened Tomorrow]]'' also employs this device,<ref name="Ackerman"/> with the protagonist receiving the next day's newspaper from an elderly colleague (who is possibly a ghost). Ackerman's anthology also highlights a short story by [[Robert Silverberg]], "What We Learned From This Morning's Newspaper".<ref name="Ackerman"/> In that story, a block of homeowners wake to discover that on November 22, they have received the ''New York Times'' for the coming December 1.<ref name="Nahin"/>{{rp|38}} As characters learn of future events affecting them through a newspaper delivered a week early, the ultimate effect is that this "so upsets the future that spacetime is destroyed".<ref name="Nahin"/>{{rp|165}} The television series ''[[Early Edition]]'', inspired by the film ''It Happened Tomorrow'',<ref>{{cite book|last1=Young|first1=R.G.|title=The Encyclopedia of Fantastic Film: Ali Baba to Zombies|date=1997|publisher=Applause|location=New York|isbn=1557832692|page=318}}</ref> also revolved around a character who daily received the next day's newspaper,<ref name="Nahin"/>{{rp|235}} and sought to change some event therein forecast to happen.
A newspaper from the future can be a fictional edition of a real newspaper, or an entirely [[List of fictional newspapers|fictional newspaper]]. [[John Buchan]]'s novel ''[[The Gap in the Curtain]]'', is similarly premised on a group of people being enabled to see, for a moment, an item in ''[[The Times|Times]]'' newspaper from one year in the future. During the [[Swedish general election, 2006|Swedish general election of 2006]], the [[Liberal People's Party (Sweden)|Swedish liberal party]] used election posters which looked like news items, called ''Framtidens nyheter'' ("News of the future"), featuring things that Sweden in the future had become what the party wanted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/fp-satsar-pa-lopsedlar-som-valaffischer/|title=Fp satsar på löpsedlar som valaffischer|publisher=Dagens nyheter|language=Swedish|trans-title=FP focuses on headlines as election posters|author=Gunnar Jonsson|date=29 June 2006|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref>
A communication from the future raises questions about the ability of humans to control their destiny.<ref name="Nahin"/>{{rp|165}} If the recipient is allowed to presume that the future is malleable, and if the future forecast affects them in some way, then this device serves as a convenient explanation of their [[motivation]]s. In ''It Happened Tomorrow'', the events that are described in the newspaper do come to pass, and the protagonist's efforts to avoid those events set up circumstances which instead cause them to come about.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} By contrast, in ''Early Edition'', the protagonist is able to successfully prevent catastrophes predicted in the newspaper, although if the protagonist does nothing, these catastrophes do come about.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
Where such a device is used, the source of the future news may not be explained, leaving it open to the reader or watcher to imagine that it might be technology, magic, an act of a god etc.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} In the H.G. Wells story,<!--what story ?--> the author writes of the newspaper that "apparently it had been delivered not by the postman, but by some other hand".{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} As in ''It Happened Tomorrow'' and ''Early Edition'', no explanation is offered for the source of the future news. Ackerman suggests that "[t]he longer that authors mush on with the tale of... the next-week's-newspaper-now, the more difficult it becomes to pull a new rarebit out of the hat".<ref name="Ackerman"/>
===Precognition=== [[Precognition]] has been explored as a form of time travel in fiction. Author [[J. B. Priestley]] wrote of it both in fiction and non-fiction, analysing testimonials of precognition and other "temporal anomalies" in his book ''Man and Time''. His books include time travel to the future through dreaming, which upon waking up results in memories from the future. Such memories, he writes, may also lead to the feeling of ''[[déjà vu]]'', that the present events have already been experienced, and are now being re-experienced.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Price|first1=Katy|title=Testimonies of precognition and encounters with psychiatry in letters to J. B. Priestley|journal=Studies in History and Philosophy of Science Part C: Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences|date=December 2014|volume=48|pages=103–111|doi=10.1016/j.shpsc.2014.07.006|pmid=25176614}}</ref> Infallible precognition, which describes the future as it truly is, leads to [[causal loop]]s, a form of which is explored in [[Newcomb's paradox]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Craig|first1=William Lane|title=Divine Foreknowledge and Newcomb's Paradox|journal=Philosophia|date=October 1987|volume=17|issue=3|pages=331–350|doi=10.1007/BF02455055|url=http://www.leaderu.com/offices/billcraig/docs/newcomb.html|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dummett|first1=Michael|title=The Seas of Language|date=1993|publisher=Clarendon Press|location=Oxford|isbn=9780198240112|pages=356, 370-375|edition=1st}}</ref> The film ''[[12 Monkeys (film)|12 Monkeys]]'' heavily deals with themes of predestination and the [[Cassandra (metaphor)|Cassandra complex]], where the protagonist who travels back in time explains that he can't change the past.<ref name="Klosterman"/>
===Time loop=== {{See also|Time loop|List of films featuring time loops}} A "time loop" or "temporal loop" is a [[plot device]] in which periods of time are repeated and re-experienced by the characters, and there is often some hope of breaking out of the cycle of repetition.<ref name="sfencyclopedia">{{cite web|author=Chelsea Quinn Yarbro|url=http://www.sf-encyclopedia.com/entry/time_loop|title=Time Loop|publisher=[[The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction]]|date=|accessdate=2015-10-18}}</ref> Time loops are sometimes referred to as [[causal loop]]s,<ref name="Klosterman"/><ref name="sfencyclopedia"/> but these two concepts are distinct. Although similar, causal loops are unchanging and self-originating, whereas time loops are constantly resetting. In a time loop when a certain condition is met, such as a death of a character or a clock reaching a certain time, the loop starts again, with one or more characters retaining the memories from the previous loop.<ref name="Jones">{{cite book|last1=Jones|first1=Matthew|authorlink1=Matt Jones (writer)|last2=Ormrod|first2=Joan|title=Time Travel in Popular Media: Essays on Film, Television, Literature and Video Games|date=2015|publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]|isbn=0786478071|page=207}}</ref> Stories with time loops commonly center on the character learning from each successive loop through time.<ref name="sfencyclopedia"/>
===Time paradox=== {{further|Temporal paradox}} Many time travel works explore the topic of disrupting causality leading to time paradoxes. One of the most commonly referred to in time travel literature is known as the [[grandfather paradox]]. Many works of fiction explore what would happen if a time traveller went back in time and changed the past, for example if they killed their own grandparents.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Langford|first1=David|authorlink=David Langford|url=http://www.sf-encyclopedia.com/entry/time_paradoxes|title=Time Paradoxes|publisher=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction|date=|accessdate=30 November 2015}}</ref>
===Time slip=== {{main|Time slip}} A time slip is a [[plot device]] used in [[fantasy]] and [[science fiction]] in which a person, or group of people, seem to [[time travel|travel through time]] by unknown means for a period of time.<ref name="io9._Time">{{cite web|title=Timeslip romance|author=Charlie Jane Anders|work=io9|date=2009-06-12|accessdate=2015-08-27|url=http://io9.com/tag/timeslip-romance}}</ref><ref name="Palmer">{{cite book|last1=Palmer|first1=Christopher|title=Philip K. Dick: Exhilaration and Terror of the Postmodern|date=2007|publisher=[[Liverpool University Press]]|location=Liverpool|isbn=9780853236184|page=146|edition=Reprint|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fsaGaFoH8UYC&pg=PA146|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> The idea of a time slip has been utilized by a number of science fiction and fantasy writers popularized at the end of the 19th century by [[Mark Twain]]'s ''[[A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court]]'', having considerable influence on later writers.<ref name="James">{{cite book|last1=James|first1=Edward|last2=Mendlesohn|first2=Farah|title=The Cambridge Companion to Fantasy Literature|date=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=9781107493735|page=106|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zWzlAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA106|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> This is one of the main plot devices of [[time travel]] stories, the other being a [[time travel|time machine]]. The difference is that in time slip stories, the protagonist typically has no control and no understanding of the process (which is often never explained at all) and is either left marooned in a past time and must make the best of it, or is eventually returned by a process as unpredictable and uncontrolled.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schweitzer|first1=Darrell|title=The Fantastic Horizon: Essays and Reviews|date=2009|publisher=Borgo Press|location=Rockville, Maryland|isbn=9781434403209|page=112|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HG-vjhQqE_cC&pg=PA112|accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref> The plot device is also popular in children's literature.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lucas|first1=Ann Lawson|title=The Presence of the Past in Children's Literature|date=2003|publisher=Praeger|location=Westport, Connecticut|isbn=9780313324833|page=113|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3mBA_EHrxvEC&pg=PA153&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cosslett|first1=Tess|title="History from Below": Time-Slip Narratives and National Identity|journal=The Lion and the Unicorn|date=1 April 2002|volume=26|issue=2|pages=243–253|doi=10.1353/uni.2002.0017|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/35545/pdf|accessdate=22 September 2017|issn=1080-6563}}</ref>
Time slips featuring a child and a realistic depiction of an earlier period enjoyed a vogue in the UK in the mid-20th century.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Successful examples include [[Alison Uttley]]'s ''A Traveller in Time'' (1939) going back to the time of [[Mary, Queen of Scots]]; [[Philippa Pearce]]'s ''[[Tom's Midnight Garden]]'' (1958) returning to the 1880s and 1890s; [[Barbara Sleigh]]'s ''[[Jessamy]]'' (1967) and Penelope Farmer's ''[[Charlotte Sometimes (novel)|Charlotte Sometimes]]'', both slipping back to the period of the [[First World War]]; [[Ruth Park]]'s ''[[Playing Beatie Bow]]'' (1980), where the slip in [[Sydney]], Australia, is to the squalor of 1873; and [[Helen Cresswell]]'s ''[[Moondial]]'', where three times periods are involved (1988, also televised).{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
===Time tourism=== A "distinct subgenre" of stories explore the possibility that time travel might be used as a means of tourism,<ref name="Kuiper"/> with travelers curious to visit periods or events such as the [[Victorian Era]], [[Crucifixion of Christ]], or some point where [[dinosaur]]s could be watched (or hunted by [[big game hunter]]s), or to meet historical figures such as [[Abraham Lincoln]] or [[Ludwig van Beethoven]].<ref name="Stableford"/> This theme can be addressed from two directions. An early example of present-day tourists travelling back to the past is [[Ray Bradbury]]{{'}}s ''A Sound of Thunder'' (1952), in which the protagonists are [[big game hunter]]s who travel to the distant past to hunt dinosaurs.<ref name="Kuiper"/> An early example of the other type, in which tourists from the future visit the present, is [[Catherine L. Moore]] and [[Henry Kuttner]]{{'}}s ''[[Vintage Season]]'' (1946), a story which was selected for inclusion in Volume Two of ''[[The Science Fiction Hall of Fame, Volume Two|The Science Fiction Hall of Fame]]'' collection.<ref name="Bova">{{cite book|last1=Bova|first1=Ben|title=[[The Science Fiction Hall of Fame, Volume Two]]|date=2003|publisher=[[Tor Books]]|location=New York|isbn=9780765305343|pages=ix-xi|edition=1st|chapter=Introduction}}</ref>
===Immortality=== {{Unsourced section|date=October 2018}} Instances of immortality are prevalent in time travel fiction. Oxford defines immortality as "the ability to live forever; eternal life." A distinct sub-thematic characteristic is warnings of said time-traveling immortals to other characters about the dangers of time travel. Some examples are 4th dimensional beings from ''[[Rick and Morty]]'', Professor Paradox from ''[[Ben 10]]'', and the Doctor from ''[[Doctor Who]]''.
===Time war=== {{See also|:Category:Temporal war fiction}} ''[[The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction]]'' describes a time war as a fictional war that is "fought across time, usually with each side knowingly using time travel ... in an attempt to establish the ascendancy of one or another version of history". Time wars are also known as "change wars" and "temporal wars".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Langford|first1=David|authorlink=David Langford|title=Changewar|url=http://www.sf-encyclopedia.com/entry/changewar|website=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction|accessdate=November 17, 2015}}</ref>
[[Paul J. Nahin|P. Nahin]] compiles a variety of examples of fictional works that raise issues framed as arising in a time war:
{{quote|Consider this passage from ''[[The Fall of Chronopolis]]'' (Bayley), a novel about a "time-war." Just after the detection of temporal invaders, we read of them that "They had come in from the future at high speed, too fast for defensive time-blocks to be set up, and had only been detected by ground-based stations deep in historical territory. If the target was to alter past events—the usual strategy in a time-war—then the empire's chronocontinuity would be significantly interfered with." And in ''Time of the Fox'' (Costello), American physicists battle KGB physicists in a war of time travelers in the past, each side attempting to change history to its advantage. In this novel the history changers isolate themselves from all the alterations taking place outside of their Time Lab, and they compare their stored historical records with those of external libraries. That allows the staff historian to adjust for each new round of changes. As the historian explains, outside of the Time Lab "History might change, but here [in the Time Lab] the past lives on."
In a novel of a galaxy-wide confrontation between humans and [[android (robot)|androids]]—''Time and Again'' (Simak)—the use of time travel to alter history is central: "A war in time ... would reach back to win its battles. It would strike at points in time and space which would not even know that there was a war. It could, logically, go back to the silver mines of Athens, to the horse and chariot of Thut- mosis III, to the sailing of Columbus. ... It would twist the fabric of the past."<ref name="Nahin"/>{{rp|267}}}}
===Hitler and World War II=== In Western fiction, one common use of time travel technology is to travel back in time and attempt to kill [[Adolf Hitler]] in an attempt to avoid [[World War II]] and the [[Holocaust]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Burnett |first1=Dean |title=Time travellers: please don’t kill Hitler |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2014/feb/21/time-travellers-kill-adolf-hitler |accessdate=October 26, 2018 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=February 21, 2014 |language=en}}</ref>
Fiction that applies the [[Novikov self-consistency principle]] that the past can't be changed results in plots where attempts to assassinate Hitler or avert the war are destined to fail, or where they actually result in the rise of Hitler as history records it.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Fiction that does allow the past to be changed often explores the unintended consequences of time travel or the [[butterfly effect]], which result in Germany and Japan winning World War II.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} This outcome is also explored in parallel world fiction such as ''[[The Man in the High Castle]]''.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}}

revision.text:
The '''Wiesbaden manifesto''' is a document written and signed by members of the [[Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives]] (MFAA) organization rejecting the plundering and removal of cultural items as spoils of war. The Allies created special commissions, such as the MFAA, to help protect famous European monuments from destruction, and after the war, to travel to territories previously occupied by the Germans to find Nazi art repositories. The allies found these plundered artworks in over 1,050 repositories in Germany and [[Austria]] at the end of [[World War II]]. The book ''The Safekeepers: Memoir of the Arts at the End of World War II'' by former [[Walter Farmer|Capt. Walter I. Farmer]] of the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] during World War II, chronicles the recovery of and restitution of discovered hidden loot of the [[Nazi plunder]], that were stolen from museums, private collections and libraries and individual [[Jewish]] emigrants and [[death camp]] prisoners.<ref>The Safekeepers: A Memoir of the Arts at the End of World War II By Walter Ings Farmer, Klaus Goldmann Published by Walter de Gruyter, 2000 {{ISBN|978-3-11-016897-6}}, 242 pages</ref>
In summer 1945, Capt. Walter Farmer became the collecting point's first director. The first shipment of artworks arriving at Wiesbaden included cases of antiquities, Egyptian art, Islamic artifacts, and paintings from the [[Kaiser Friedrich Museum]]. The collecting point also received materials from the [[Reichsbank]] and [[Nazi]] looted [[Poles|Polish]] liturgical collections. At its height, Wiesbaden stored, identified, and restituted approximately 700,000 individual objects, including paintings and sculptures.<ref>http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=10388</ref> The collecting point not only cataloged and restitutued items, but also kept them away from the [[Soviet Army]] and wartime reparations.<ref>http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=10388</ref><ref>Opritsa D. Popa. Bibliophiles and Bibliothieves: The Search for the Hildebrandslied and the Willehalm Codex. Berlin and New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2003. xvi + 265 pp. $58.00 (cloth), {{ISBN|978-3-11-017730-5}}</ref>
When his superiors ordered that he send to the U.S. 202 German-owned paintings in his custody, Capt. Farmer and 35 others who were in charge of the Wiesbaden collection point gathered to draw up what has become known as the Wiesbaden Manifesto on November 7, 1945, declaring "We wish to state that, from our own knowledge, no historical grievance will rankle so long or be the cause of so much justified bitterness as the removal for any reason of a part of the heritage of any nation even if that heritage may be interpreted as a prize of war." Among the co-signers was Lieutenant [[Charles Percy Parkhurst]] of the U.S. Navy.<ref>Walter I. Farmer. The Safekeepers: A Memoir of the Arts at the End of World War II. Berlin and New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2000. x + 242 pp., {{ISBN|978-3-11-016897-6}}</ref>
After three years of debate, U.S. President [[Harry S. Truman]] ordered that the paintings be returned to Germany in 1948.
